moves.1. d4: Against this strong player, I'm going to try to equalize in the opening and see what his plans are.
It seems to be a Torre at this pont. I know the opening from White's perspective and should be able to defend.
moves.5... Qb6 6. Qc2 Nc6 7. Nbd2 Bd7 8. Bd3 R: Now here I was tempting him to exchange on f6 and he finally did.
moves.12... gxf6 13. Re1 Kf8: I have no problem with this set-up. The g file is open and the extra f pawn is useful in pressuring the center and keeping knights at bay. The downside is a loose king position and an isolated h pawn.
moves.14. Nf1 Kg7 15. g3: Here, I think, he startes to go wrong. His f pawn is blocked and and the f1 knight should have gone to g3.
moves.15... Ne7 16. Qc2 Bb5: Bb5!  Now I can exchange off his powerful bishop and his attack is slowed considerably.
moves.17. Bxb5 Qxb5 18. a3 Qc6: The king on g7 seems to be a lot safer, my rooks are connected and I have the c file.
moves.19. Ne3 b5 20. Qe2 a5 21. Red1 Ng6 22. a: Releasing some tension with c5. Since he gave up a pawn to open the b file, I should think he would consider doing something there or just taking the d pawn.
moves.24... Bc7 25. Rd2 Rcb8 26. Nd1 Rb4: His plan, whatever that is, is too slow. I have a real advantage here.
moves.27. Nc3: With this move, he offered a draw and I accepted. After taking back the pawn, there might have followed an exchange of rooks with his knight going to c6, but then ...Nc8 pretty much ends his counterlpay.
